ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I've gained a greater understanding of the various systems within the body and have genuinely enjoyed the vast majority of the topics we have discussed. I feel that I have a strong base on which to build the rest of my degree.
I developed a detailed understanding of many key physiological processes.
I learned so so much about how body systems work and integrate and are well/optimally designed! And I got a new appreciation for how bodily systems function!
A good overview of most fields of physiology. Understanding the intersection of physics, chemistry, biology, and anatomy which makes the field.
I learned so much about how the body functions and maintains homeostasis.

Very good overview into a lot of the important organ systems of the body through an engineering lens. The course also focused on application of the facts that can be learned in a textbook onto real world scenarios through clinical vignettes and exam questions (that made you think critically about how to apply your knowledge on certain physiological systems).

Mechanics of different physiological systems, with a focus on the cardiovascular system, kidneys, respiratory, and endocrine system. How to model these systems in MatLab and determine how different parameters/factors affect their regulation or equilibrium.
so much knowledge about the body systems; amazing intro to what a medical school course is like

I mainly took this course to help me with MCAT content. It'll go through most of the major bio content you will need for it including the cardiovascular system, the respiratory system, the kidneys, the endocrine system, etc. Would highly recommend if you don't want to self-study these concepts for the MCAT (though this class will go into more detail than is on the exam).
Gained a lot of insight into the way that we function as humans
Learnt all about the heart, blood, hormones, and a bunch of other stuff. Really a hell of a lot of things. Also applied a lot of these skills in medical settings which was cool.
A way more in depth of the body! I had taken this class before at my undergrad, but this version was more detailed and went over different body parts
overview of physiological systems, emphasis on broad mechanistic concepts that are common to different systems
Integrate different pieces of knowledge together
I know some knowledge about physiological systems which I didn't know before taking this course, for example, membrane, renal systems, muscle systems, lung and so on.
I learned a lot of things this semester in this class. I learned essentially about almost all the systems of the body and their basic anatomies.
Learned tons about physiological systems. It was a lot of content. However, the content was actually interesting/relevant to what I want to do in the future, which made it easier to absorb.

Great overview of the functioning of the major organ systems of the body. I liked the focus on problem solving and applying physiological principles to better understand various healthy/disease states.
Multiple facts about physiology.
I learned a ton about the different systems of the body. I hope it will help prepare me for MCATs.
I feel like I learned everything in this class. Basically, if you want to understand Grey's Anatomy, take this class.

I developed a deep understanding of the systems of the human body and how they interconnect to maintain life functions. The topics covered in this course include the cardiovascular system, the renal system, the digestive system, the central nervous system, the pulmonary system, and more. The lessons on each of these systems displayed common themes that highlight the main principles of human physiology.
About how different organ systems interact with one another

I learned about the structure and function of the cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, renal, somatosensory, visual, respiratory, endocrine, and reproductive systems. The nervous system was covered briefly.
In-depth knowledge of physiological functions of human body.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It is great that we can cover so many different systems in their complexity but simultaneously this is difficult because a speed is required to accomplish this that doesn't necessarily give time for the proper depth of discussion that would lead to clearer understanding of the material. The variety of teaching styles was also a little difficult to keep up with as we change professors regularly. A strength of the course is that the professors and TFs understand this and do as much as they can to accommodate us both in the grading of quizzes and exams.
Too much information taught, cut it down by a few systems

Strengths: This course covers a lot of material, rather quickly, however it also felt very relevant and interesting so it was exciting to learn about each topic. I think the TAs and Peer Tutors supported our learning well.

Weaknesses: There is so much content that I wonder if having four exams rather than three would be beneficial. That way each exam has less content on them, and the fourth could even be given in the last week of class to avoid an exam during finals week. I do think that recording these lectures or providing old recordings would be highly beneficial to learning as I found the slide insufficient to review lectures that I had attended. Additionally, it would be helpful to have more clarity about grading cut-offs for undergraduate students.

The class was well designed and delivered interestingly every time (especially for 9a), and the distribution go work was nicely allocated in a fair way (esp. with quizzes, section, and the exams). Im not sure if I have anything to say against the class or say that could be done betterthe class is a well oiled machine!

Strengths: covers a lot of content that is very interesting. Lectures on endocrinology were a great example of how most lectures should have been taught-they were lengthy but clear and w/ interesting clinical vignettes. Probs good prep for med school. 
Weaknesses: Tests can be brutal and material overwhelming. Grad labs feel poorly guided and not super useful without proper explanations.
I enjoyed the lectures and the discussion sections were super super helpful!

Strengths: The textbook was very helpful. It is one of the better written textbooks that I have used and offered a lot of interesting facts that are not always covered in lectures. It is a great extension of lecture materials while also succinctly explaining key concepts introduced during lecture. The grading scheme for the graduate class facilitated hands on learning (during the discussion section).
Weaknesses: While the exams were structured to be more focused on applying facts and the key concepts, there were still multiple choice questions and true or false questions that tested your brute memorization of the material. Sometimes, it felt like the multiple choice questions were intentionally worded for you to make a simple memory mistake.

Strengths are the learning resources (slides, textbook, office hours, discussion section), the graduate lab section, and the quizzes as an opportunity to practice / test my understanding in a non pressure way. Weakness are the exams, which were often a time crunch and included questions that relied on rote memorization of facts, but alas, I guess that is the study of physiology / biology.

weaknesses: lectures sometimes difficult to follow, final so much more difficult than midterms
strengths: best TAs ever, interesting content

The strengths are the learning objectives which are listed at the end of each lecture. I would highly recommend being very comfortable with those as you approach exam time. The kidney lectures did not have any, so in the future, that might be helpful to have.

Discussion section was a huge part of the course. It was a great review of everything that we went over in class, and served as a way to emphasize points that may have flown under the radar in lecture. I don't like the fact that I felt like I'd be hanging on for dear life if I didn't go to a discussion section for a class that already meets 3 times a week, so I feel like the lectures could do a better job of emphasizing key points but aside from that it was a fair course.

I thought the course was really great in general. I wish the graduate labs were a bit more diverse than just running code on computers, but overall the information covered was really interesting and the course requirements weren't too harsh.

I think the lectures are quite poor. The slides are impossible to study from. If you're someone like me who has auditory processing disorders or has quite simply never learned well in lecture style environment and prefers to learn through office hours and independent study, I don't believe I should be penalized for that. AND the fact that the lectures ARE recorded but not given is dumb. I feel like they are trying to make the class harder than it needs to be because it has that reputation of being a hard class. Its ridiculous that you get ONE shot at getting down the lecture material for a topic that is known to have loads of information. Physiology is not conceptually difficult. There is just a lot of information. so not having adequate study materials for outside of class just puts students at a disadvantage for?? what reason?? . it helps no one.

conceptual focus was very strong, level of detail and speed was inconsistent between different systems - some felt too fast, others too slow, others incompletely covered and others too in depth.
expectations for level of detail on exams was unclear.

Strength: the logic flow is good, and the concepts are good
Weakness: Length of exam

The organization of this class is good, and the teaching of professors and TFs is professional. However, I feel like there are too many things I need to focus on, I understand there are many points in physiology, but I still hope that we can focus on the most important things, for other things, we may study by our interests. For example, it would be great if all exams had required questions and selected questions like the final, the most important questions can be covered by the most important points, while other deeper questions can be covered by selected questions, and we can select the part of them to answer. Because it is really difficult to memorize everything in a week or even shorter time.

This was a really great course. The strengths are that you really do get to learn a lot of physiology in one semester but it is a ton of information to really process and comprehend in one semester, especially for the exams. I feel like this course should be two separate classes. It often times feels like we jump from one topic to the next without a smooth transition. It becomes hard to keep up as the semester goes on and there is a lot of memorization you need to do, in my opinion, in order to do well on the exams. It would be nice to have the exams be open book as it'd be a testament that a true understanding rather than the ability to memorize is what's needed to do well on the exams.
I would normalize the grading for quizzes across TFs. Although the TFs grade using the same rubric, some tended to take off more points for certain things than others.
Weakness: No recorded lecture, difficult to review slides on their own. Would prefer if recordings were released a week before exam to encourage attendance but also provide opportunity for review.

Strengths: The focus on applying physiological principles (not just memorizing facts). The lab section for grad students was very useful for understanding the underlying biophysics and definitely removed the pressure to do very well for exams. The weekly quizzes were very helpful in making sure we revised concepts regularly and got feedback on the areas we did not understand very well

Weaknesses: Course tries to cover too much content in the time we have. I appreciated the units where we did multiple lectures per system (lung, kidney, heart) as I was able to gain a deeper understanding. Some of the other lectures (like reproductive physiology) were important but very rushed, so maybe other lectures could have been cut to allow more time to expand on these topics.

Strength: amazing professors and TAs who are very knowledgeable, kind, understanding, and willing to help you. They also listen to feedback and actually enact change in response. 
Weakness: first exam was long, but they fixed it immediately.
The lectures were variable in quality. Some were engaging, but in others it felt like the instructor was just reading off slides that contained regurgitations of the text book material.

Strengths: INCREDIBLY engaging content. VERY well taught with kind professors. Learning objectives are very helpful. Realistic expectations for students. A very challenging but rewarding class. 

Weakness: Professors' office hours are all virtual which made them intimidating to attend. Would prefer to have had these in person.

This course is very engaging and well taught. While the pace of the course is high as there is a lot of content to cover, the professors do a good job of clearly communicating each lesson and providing opportunities for students to seek help. Also, for students who are interested in medicine or are passionate about physiology, it is easy to put in the effort to keep up with the class. One thing I particularly liked about the course is that, by attending section, your grade on the weekly quizzes can be boosted to a 100% if you score above a 50%. This is helpful because it takes the pressure off of the weekly quizzes and allows you to view them more as a learning challenge/opportunity than a stressful assignment. The material in the course is already challenging, so having an opportunity to practice your learning in a low stakes context and then ask questions at your discussion section is very helpful and much appreciated.
One weakness of the course is that, apart from exams, students do not have opportunities to receive feedback on their learning. However, they can certainly seek feedback if they wish on the weekly quizzes, which is good.
The course material is too much! If you take this course, intend it to be the primary focus of your semester.

Strengths: Assignments were all helpful for studying material, Labs were super helpful in understanding information, Weekly quizzes were a great way to review material

Weaknesses: On quizzes and long answer exam questions it was unclear what answers were expected. Even if you were right and answered the question, you would only get all points if you psychically anticipate what terms would be included in the rubric. Maybe a word bank or more specific questions would be helpful if you continue to grade this way. We spent so much time on the kidneys and so little time on more complicated systems like sensing.

This course had VERY comprehensive lectures with uploaded slides, which were helpful for review. I would have appreciated lectures being recorded as well. I loved having sections, as the TAs were very helpful in explaining concepts. More review sessions led by the professors would have been helpful.

The main weakness of this course is the pacing of the lectures. Most of the lectures were rushed and the instructors seemed like they did not have enough time to cover all of the material they intended to. Overall, the amount of material that students must learn in this course is much greater than other undergraduate courses. This course would be greatly improved if a separate course was made specifically for Biomedical Engineering. This could help the course have pacing that is more appropriate for an undergraduate prerequisite, rather than a graduate or upper level undergraduate course. The course could also be improved by changing the weekly quiz assignments to facilitate students learning at the depth required for exams. The quizzes were typically broad and open ended, while the exams required students to show very detailed understanding. It would have been beneficial to have additional practice to help students prepare.

Strengths: an amazingly comprehensive summary of our biological systems, save the immune system. You can tell that Saltzman and Campbell really care about making sure students understand the content. 
Weaknesses: I really wish this class were lectures of 75 minutes as opposed to just 50. Even though I never felt like I was learning meaningless content, we simply never seemed to have enough time to cover all of it, and at least half the lectures felt too rushed. The difficulty and format of the exams also differed quite a bit from exam to exam, something that definitely could have been improved to support the students.
Lots of student support to facilitate learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they enjoy biology and understanding the chemistry and mechanisms of the body, yes. I would NOT recommend to anyone who is just trying to complete their science requirement or doesn't genuinely enjoy the subject because it is more difficult than a lot of classes.
If you are interested in physiology yes, but I would recommend Credit/D/failing the class unless you need it for your major

For a pre-med student, it was helpful to get a sense of how much information there is to know in physiology and develop study strategies to begin to learn it all. If you're ready for flashcards, hundreds of slides, and more information than you think there is space in your brain for, then yes I would recommend it!

Absolutely! This was such an interesting course, well taught, and gives you such an appreciation a better intuition for how the body and body systems work! So so cool! One of best classes I have taken at Yale!

Yes but only if you are committed to memorizing and learning a large amount of content. The material is interesting and pretty much exactly what you'd expect. It's great prep for med school and the MCAT, although the question yield is probably not super high.
yes! If interested in how the body works, this is a great intersection of a lot of bio, chem, and some physics concepts.
Yes, especially if you are pre-med. This course is a glimpse of what medical school is like and covers many important topics for the MCAT. I taught me how to think about the body at a systems level.
yes, absolutely, especially if you are planning to go into medicine

I would recommend the grad version of this course to undergrads looking to fulfill the upper-level MCDB requirement. I would also recommend this course to people that are planning to take the MCAT in the future.
Only if you need it. Too difficult to take as an exploratory course

Sure! The content was very interesting, and the workload was honestly appropriate for the amount of things you get to cover in such a short timespan. If you really want to delve into how a lot of the most important systems in the body work and don't have a horrific course schedule, this course is a great option to do so.
This course was almost good. Campbell and Waltzman were great. The organization of this class, feedback, and resources is probably the worst I've ever taken so no.
This is a really cool course that teaches you physiology and a little anatomy. Very scientific way of learning about the body and processes, great premed MCDB course.
yes, good introduction to physiology and overlap with material covered on mcat.
Yes
Not really. The course and grading are tough, I only recommend students who are required to take.

If they needed to learn physiology, yes. This class is already very hard as is, but having Mark and Stuart as the dynamic duo + Peter for the renal classes makes the class much more bearable. They are all excellent professors and they teach the topics they are experts in, so you really get to gain a deep understanding of the material from them.
Yes. It's a lot of work. But, it's worth it.
Very premed  challenging but rewarding

It is a very useful course, but I would only recommend this to students with a genuine interest in physiology (not meant for students who are just curious). Students would also need to be able to dedicate 4-5 hrs a week to studying and doing the weekly assignments-- it is not easy to take this course if you are unable to dedicate the time to it.
Yes. It was very interesting and the professors and TAs are great. It just required a lot of time to do well, which may not be ideal for some students.
Yes I have and will continue to recommend this class. Like I said, it is a challenging class, but it is also a wonderful class!

I would recommend this course to another student at Yale, especially if they are interested in human biology or are pre-med. This course provides a very  thorough look at the systems of the human body, and while it is a lot of information to learn, it is very interesting. The professors are also very good instructors and are clearly passionate about the subject, so they are happy to answer any questions you might have.
Sure. It was really interesting and well structured. It is a lot of work, so I wouldn't suggest it for fun.

This is a really great class to learn how the human body works. HOWEVER, there are greater issues to taking this course than just the high workload. You should also consider how many bio classes you have already taken. This is where everything comes together, so I would recommend taking it towards the end of your Yale career if possible.

I would not recommend this course to a student who isn't required to take it. It is extremely challenging, and the course is not organized in a way that facilitates learning the difficulty of the material. For students who are more prepared for this rigor, I do think the course offers a lot of information on human physiological systems that could be very beneficial for those considering medical/pharmacy programs.
Absolutely. However, the class is quite difficult and if it is not required for your major (as it is for BME), I might recommend taking it Cr/D/F to reduce some of the stress of taking it.
Yes, if necessary or particularly interested.
